instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_PWM: What is LCD_BKLT_PWM? LCD_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR: What is PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR? PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR is PPBUS_G3H after it has passed through a backlight fuse and a transistor that allows power through when BKLT_PLT_RST_L and LCD_BKLT_EN are present. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
No liquid damage.
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.4V
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> is 0V
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is 0V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL> is 0V
Tried with another LCD too...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: Yes. Tried with flashlight from back.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Three possibilities

1) <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is less than 3.4v so the machine thinks it is closed, and not turning on the backlight.
2) <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> is bad and shorting it to ground, which never happens
3) <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is toast.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: I bet the measurement in the first post were done without an LCD connected. Enable and PWM being low with an image present just doesn't happen.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
ok, #4

you aren't plugging in a screen and expecting backlight.

I am giving you the credit that you actually are measuring with a screen plugged in. Please tell me you are.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: No PWM :(. I would change the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and pray it comes back.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: Either resetting PRAM will fix or <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is fried. Quick fix is sending <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> directly to <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>, real fix is replacing <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>. Obviously, no brightness control with quick fix.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: Louis you are forgetting that the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> could pull low PWM too. Also without PWM signal I would expect at least a little boost. My first guess is still the 8550.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
I changed <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. (not working the backlight)
 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> directly to <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>(working)
Thank you! Maybe the smc.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: Bad MUX probably. Working now so fine.
